summary:
Based on the passage:

Paul Merson restarted his row with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on for only seven minutes (83rd minute) in their 0-0 draw with Burnley, tweeting about the short appearance time. This follows a previous row where Merson had criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team. Merson was proven wrong when Townsend scored an equalizer for England against Italy and subsequently admitted his mistake, stating he holds his hands up when wrong. Townsend had previously tweeted back at Merson after scoring against Italy. Despite bad feeling seeming to have passed, Merson had another dig after the Burnley match.

Based on the passage:

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old Japanese forward, Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the move is completed this summer, Muto would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane claims the offer is not connected to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps, is honoured by the offer but has not yet decided whether to join the club. He has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, scoring 16 goals in 37 appearances overall, including 3 goals in 4 games this season. A Â£4 million deal has been suggested.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The embarrassed guard, who dropped his rifle and knocked his bearskin, quickly got back up. The incident was caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The fall may have been caused by slipping on the manhole cover, possibly due to metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence would not comment on the incident.

Based on the passage:

A remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which had over 100 million viewers, is being produced. The new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," will air in 2016 and be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History networks. It tells the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who starred as Kinte in the original, is a co-executive producer. The remake will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and consult scholars for authenticity, aiming to reach both original fans and a new generation.

Based on the passage:

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims palace aides tried to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978. He alleges he was pinned to a chair and groped on his first day, leaving the job immediately afterwards. He contacted palace officials again last year after inquiries into historical abuse began, but claims his complaints were ignored for months before police were notified. Police are now investigating his claims. A retired royal aide was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated they will cooperate with the police probe.

Based on the passage:

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video they made set to the theme from '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The clip, which features them rapping, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The video includes details about their life, trying to conceive, finding out about the pregnancy, and ends with a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple stated the video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby and that its success was completely unexpected.

Based on the passage:

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the

Based on the passage:

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after officials said his parents dangled him over the edge and he slipped. His parents rescued him before emergency services arrived. The boy suffered minor bumps and bruises and an injured leg and is in stable condition. The cheetahs did not attack or approach him. The zoo closed the exhibit and plans to press child endangerment charges against the family/mother, citing eyewitness accounts indicating the child was likely dangled over the railing.

Based on the passage:

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which previously enforced the 30mph limit, has been turned to point directly at a house's front door. The camera has not been working for over two years, since March 2013, when all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were switched off due to obsolete technology. It is unknown who re-pointed the camera, but Birmingham City Council is aware and will send an engineer to the site, potentially removing the camera completely. The council is developing plans for a pilot using digital technology but this camera is not included.

Based on the passage:

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA). Bolt stated he is fit, healthy, and ready to run and aims to make his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure that Bolt was available and expects "sprint magic". The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Based on the passage:

Neymar and Dani Alves, accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella, watched Barcelona's basketball team play El Clasico against Real Madrid in the Euro League. Barcelona won the basketball game 85-80, although Real Madrid remain top of their Euro League division by points difference.

Separately, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile, a match where he faced brutal challenges, including Gary Medel appearing to stamp on him.

Before the international break, Barcelona's football team won their El Clasico against Real Madrid, which put them four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar and his Barcelona team-mates are

Based on the passage:

Italy is coping with a rising wave of migrants from Africa and the Middle East. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with 20 SOS calls received on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants are missing based on survivor testimony about a capsized ship carrying 550 people, but the Italian Coast Guard cannot confirm this incident and has found no evidence at sea. There has been a recent upsurge in migrant boats and rescues. Italy registered over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first three months of 2015, with 2,000 rescued in the Channel of Sicily in the first weekend of April. Most migrants are from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as transit. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment.

Based on the passage:

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger does not know the exact reason Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, but he is glad he did. Sanchez chose Arsenal after leaving Barcelona and has made an instant impression in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger was aware of Liverpool's interest and thought it could be linked to negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praised Sanchez's qualities, including efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit. Wenger also played down speculation linking Arsenal with Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling and praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for developing his team, noting Liverpool scored over 100 goals last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark). The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The current record is 52.491km, set by Rohan Dennis in February. Tickets for the event go on sale from April 19 (Â£49, Â£39, Â£29, online only) and it will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins recently finished his Team Sky career and will ride for his eponymous team before preparing for the Hour attempt.

Based on the passage:

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup singles match, calling it an 'eye-opener' and stating she wasn't as ready for the claycourt season as she thought. The US team was beaten 3-2 by Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing their doubles match 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This defeat resulted in the US being relegated to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez commented that the team needs to work harder to get back into the World Group.

Based on the passage:

River Plate are keen to sign former forward Radamel Falcao but admit the deal is complicated. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian stated they "dream of Falcao Garcia" and "the doors are open." Falcao spent eight years with River Plate before leaving in 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances over four seasons in the first team. He has struggled on loan at Manchester United this season, scoring four Premier League goals, and his future there is uncertain. However, he has recently been in good goalscoring form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time record with 24 goals.

Based on the passage:

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has partnered with the dry shampoo brand Batiste. She is the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The international campaign launched with a TV advertisement featuring her latest single, 'Mirror Man'. Campaign images show her with various hairstyles against a city background. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency. Ella uses the product regularly, and her management highlighted the synergy between her and the brand.

Based on the passage:

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, causing shock among family and friends of Aaron Siler, whom Torres shot and killed on March 14. Siler was shot after he 'armed himself with a weapon' following a pursuit; he was wanted on a felony warrant. Siler's family and friends call the billboard disrespectful and want it removed, feeling it implies thanking the officer for the killing. The Kenosha Professional Police Association paid for the billboard to thank the community for support, stating no offense was intended. Torres is on leave pending the ongoing investigation into Siler's death by the state Division of Criminal Investigation. Torres also shot Terry Knight on March 4, which was ruled justified.

Based on the passage:

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan in the southeastern town of Negur. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces. The militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan, and Iranian officials asked Pakistani authorities to catch surviving assailants. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. According to Pakistani media, Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group that targets Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan, and has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on Iranian territory. Iranian authorities say militants flee back into Pakistan after attacks, and Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control them. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism, is investigating, asked Iran for evidence, and stated militants entering Pakistan would be apprehended.

Based on the passage:

Japanese politicians discussed real-life "Space Invaders" (UFOs). In Japan's parliament (the Diet), Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Nakatani stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. He explained that the ASDF scrambles jets for visual observation if an unidentified flying object could violate airspace, sometimes finding birds or other objects, but no cases believed to be from other than Earth. Inoki claims to have seen a UFO but doesn't know if aliens exist. The passage notes this isn't the first time Japanese politicians discussed this, mentioning a 2007 discussion by a previous Defense Minister about legal ramifications of defense against space invasion.

Based on the passage:

A passenger, Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He reportedly stood on the rim because he was worried the seat was not clean. The toilet shattered, cutting him, and he was found bleeding after calling travelling companions for help. He was taken to a hospital in Hefei where he received dozens of stitches. Authorities believed the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting, not standing. The passenger reportedly confessed to friends he was squatting but later told police he was sitting.

Based on the passage:

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama (37) has a new series of images from his latest book, roughly translated as "Daughter and Salary Man". The photos feature teenage daughters and their fathers. In each picture, the father leaps into the air next to his daughter. Daughters are typically po-faced, look directly into the camera, and wear casual clothing, while fathers wear sharp suits and pull energetic poses (some older ones look slightly pained). According to the photographer, this allows fathers to express their fun side. The families pose in front of various Japanese landmarks. Very little else is known about the pictures, but they are generating online interest.

Based on the passage:

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director is a major talking point, but focus is also on the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is aiming for a sensational return to the England set-up, and Downton's sacking has paved the way for this potential return. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey to try and force his way back into the Test team, having last played internationally during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year. He was recently at the KIA Oval for the Surrey team photo shoot ahead of the new season, showing a range of emotions, appearing thoughtful but also jovial and joking with team-mates and photographers.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. He was initially fired on Wednesday after a poor run but reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, he was sacked again after Ceahlaul lost 2-0 on Saturday, a result that left the club 16th in the standings, six points adrift of safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender capped 25 times, had replaced Florin Marin in January and was the club's third coach this season. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Based on the passage:

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao regrets his failed season-long loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao moved to Old Trafford last summer but has struggled, scoring only four goals all season, and Manchester United is unlikely to pay the Â£46 million to make the transfer permanent. Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League, although he notes Falcao was not feeling well and may have needed more atmosphere there. Falcao's struggles are linked to his performance before suffering a serious knee injury.

Based on the passage:

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a man who robbed a dairy in Union St, east Christchurch, on Saturday around 12:30 pm. The man, described as 'very tall', wore a 'distinctive' cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. He demanded cash from the owner's daughter and took the till drawer and about $1500 cash. Police were called, noted no weapons were used, and the robber remains at large. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Based on the passage:

A video showing a crocodile swimming in a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The dog belonged to the local bike shop owner, and the large crocodile held it for hours. Tourist Tim Weston witnessed the event, describing it as a shock. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, living in mangroves and a nearby sanctuary, and are increasingly close to humans due to urbanization. Social media users reacted with horror to the video.

Based on the passage:

Teacher Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the session had finished and altering some himself at Mitton Manor Primary School. This resulted in the Department for Education annulling all the school's SATs results for the year. Guffick lost his job and was banned from teaching for at least two years. He admitted the allegations and accepted it was unacceptable professional conduct, although he claimed he only asked pupils to make answers more legible. A conduct panel found his conduct dishonest but not seriously dishonest.

Based on the passage:

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time and is currently third-choice, is married to stunning Swedish model Misse Beqiri. They have been dating since 2012, married last year in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius, and have a son together. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is active on Instagram, posting modelling photos and having over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard has shared aspects of their life together on Instagram. Despite his lack of success on the pitch since joining in 2010, the passage indicates he is doing well off it.

Based on the passage:

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities following incidents involving Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both being pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers did not discipline them and wants to move past the issue. Captain Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving a suspension, though Rodgers has not revealed if he will recall him. Rodgers' sole priority is reaching the FA Cup final, viewing past losses as part of the journey to success.

Based on the passage:

Mesut Ozil returned to London after international duty, posting a picture relaxing with his dog. He played for Germany in their 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia on Sunday. Ozil is preparing for Arsenal's Premier League match against Liverpool at the weekend and is expected to start after missing the last game due to illness. Rumors about him being in a Berlin nightclub after missing the Newcastle game were rubbished by manager Arsene Wenger. Since returning from

Based on the passage:

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated the club is "very happy" with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him. Bartomeu refuted speculation about Enrique's future, highlighting that Enrique took charge last summer, has a contract until 2016, and has impressed during his tenure. He expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance and hard work, noting that Barcelona is capable of winning three trophies. The passage also mentions Barcelona's recent win against Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Based on the passage:

Jordan Henderson is set to sign a new long-term contract with Liverpool. The deal is expected to be worth around Â£100,000 per week and will run until the summer of 2020. He is the third player to agree an extension after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho and is considered for the club captain role when Steven Gerrard departs.

Based on the passage:

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering bringing him back. Luis signed from Atletico last July but has struggled at Chelsea, which Atletico hopes provides leverage. Luis recently played for Brazil and is now focused on the Premier League run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging the team to stay focused and win every game, and Luis feels the team is prepared for the difficult remaining matches.

Based on the passage:

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee during a try on March 27 was overturned on appeal. Hughes was initially shown a red card and banned after a panel ruled he was 'reckless', despite accepting there was no intent. The decision faced criticism. George North was knocked out by the collision (his third in two months) and advised to take a month off. Hughes missed a match due to the ban. The appeal panel, hearing new evidence, concluded the incident was accidental with no foul play, upholding Wasps' appeal and rescinding the red card and ban. Hughes is now free to return to action.

Based on the passage:

Fiery sunsets were seen in Washington and other parts of the Pacific Northwest (Oregon, British Columbia), caused by smoke from raging wildfires in Siberia. The fires started from farmers burning grass but spread rapidly on April 14 due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Lingering smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean. The intense red color is due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate, which is more intense during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish

Based on the passage:

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found and returned to her, but it had been modified with new red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig posted on Facebook thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. However, the car smelled strongly of cigarettes and marijuana and needs professional cleaning. Schoenig is also creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car.

Based on the passage:

Manchester City players face losing Â£500,000 each in bonuses, totaling Â£12 million for the squad, if they fail to qualify for the Champions League group stages. These incentivized contracts help the club stay within financial fair play requirements. City's European hopes are uncertain after losing the Manchester derby, leaving them in fourth place. Manager Manuel Pellegrini stated the team has let their season "disintegrate" and been "thrown into the garbage". Failure to qualify could also impact their ability to sign world-class players.

Based on the passage:

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' and an inspiration. This occurred after the 1-1 draw between England and Italy, where Buffon earned his 147th cap and Hart earned his 50th cap. Hart stated he is still learning and watches Buffon. Hart expressed delight at receiving his 50th cap at the Juventus Stadium and his desire to keep earning more caps.

Based on the passage:

Chipotle is entering the food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app. This service will offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. Customers will be charged a nine percent service charge, plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. The passage notes Chipotle had previously turned down offers from other third-party delivery services.

Based on the passage:

The parents of the youngest Boston Marathon bombing victim,
Based on the passage, a Boeing

Based on the passage:

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed cargo spacecraft called Dragon from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. The company attempted to land a rocket stage on a floating barge for the first time but was unsuccessful; the rocket landed but too hard for survival and tipped over. SpaceX founder Elon Musk wants to cut costs by reusing rockets like airplanes. The Dragon spacecraft is en route to the ISS to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker. The space station crew will unpack it for about five weeks, then fill it with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other items to send back to Earth. Dragon will then leave the station and splashdown in the Pacific Ocean off California. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS, and the company was the first private space contractor to dock with the station. Tuesday's launch was the second attempt for this mission after Monday's was scrubbed due to weather.

Based on the passage:

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas. This wedding is the prize for an Elvis-obsessed couple who won a contest run with NBC's Today show. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will marry on Thursday, April 23. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla was involved in the chapel's design and insisted there be no impersonators. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples entered the contest by submitting a video or photos and an explanation.

Based on the passage:

Liverpool beat Newcastle United 2-0. Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson, who played his 47th game of the season, thinks his side could catch Manchester City in the Premier League. Liverpool are four points behind Manchester City, who lost 4-2 at Manchester United. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring, and Joe Allen scored the second goal.

Based on the passage:

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several saves in the second half to secure the win. This victory was important for Roma's Champions League place hopes, moving them provisionally ahead of Lazio, and ended their run of seven matches without a home win. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and they remained fifth. Security was tight for the match due to a past incident, with measures including barring residents from the Campania region from buying tickets and deploying 1,000 police, but no problems were reported.

Based on the passage:

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspired season in League One, entrenched in mid-table. Their match against Fleetwood Town resulted in a goalless draw (0-0) at the Keepmoat Stadium, which tested patience. The media team faced a challenge compiling highlights for the 0-0 draw and produced a very short video (27 seconds total, 14 seconds match action) for the club's YouTube channel, showing only the kick off, a goal kick, and the final whistle, describing it as a "must-see video". Managers were on the touchline during the draw.

Based on the passage:

The passage describes the remarkable relationship between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid. Giroux interacts with the fish by dipping his hand in the tank, cupping, stroking, and massaging it. The fish appears to enjoy this, relaxing, staying still, and returning for more attention, even swimming up his arm and circling his fingers. This relationship developed after Giroux removed other fish that were bullying the cichlid and began hand-feeding it, making the fish more sociable. The

Based on the passage:

Ben Stokes is back in the England team after a year of ups and downs. He broke his wrist punching a locker last year, which reminds him to channel his aggression correctly. Known as a

Based on the passage:

The Wales vs. Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out. The match features the top two sides in Group B, both with 11 points from five games, with Belgium leading on goal difference. Wales is in their best position to qualify for a major tournament since 1958. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel increased expectations and created a buzz, leading to overwhelming demand for tickets. The match is at the Cardiff City Stadium, which the squad prefers, and UEFA rules prevented changing the venue to the Millennium Stadium.
England coach John Peacock has named the squad for next month's UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions are the defending champions, having

Based on the passage:

Manchester City is keen to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth setup. He has also attracted attention from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously rejected a move to Barcelona at age 12 for family and study reasons. City has held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to agree on a compensation package, as Manuel Pellegrini looks to build for the future.

Based on the passage:

On The Jeremy Kyle show, a woman named Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages, accused her friend and housemate, Jamie, of stealing Â£207 saved for a gravestone for her baby, Daniel James. A lie detector test revealed Jamie had taken the money, and he also confessed via Facebook message, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal, expressing the importance of the gravestone for her baby.

Based on the passage:

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis on Wednesday in northern Iraq. Most of those released were women and children, along with the ill or elderly. This follows ISIS attacks last summer that killed, captured, and displaced

Based on the passage:

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team and England side. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation, produced by Copa90 using still photographs, features some of his best goals and celebrations from the season, including goals against Chelsea, Arsenal, and on his England debut. Titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', the video is released ahead of the awards ceremony where he is nominated for both awards and competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Based on the passage:

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher backed Rodgers, stating his future shouldn't be determined by one game and noting difficulties with new players bedding in. He added that Rodgers needs to identify areas for improvement and ensure future signings are right for the team to aim for a trophy and a top-four finish next season. The passage also states Jamie Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, providing coaching in schools in deprived areas through his 23 Foundation.

Based on the passage:

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security deemed it a security risk because it resembled a prohibited item. He was frisked by security officers. His father described the checks as 'ludicrous' and staff as 'over-zealous'. East Midlands Airport defended the decision, stating safety is the priority and regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, while also offering to post the toy back. James was bought a replacement toy gun after returning from his holiday.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife. He listed requirements for his ideal partner, including loving pets, being a non-drinker/smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with their hands, a good cook, great in bed, enjoying the outdoors but also being a 'princess'. He offered benefits such as accommodation, potentially a company car, phone, and laptop, free gym membership, and promised to spend money and provide 'lots of benefits', considering 'all reasonable offers'. Rich described himself as 31, 175cm tall, athletic build, white, heavily tattoo'd, brown hair/eyes, a non-drinker/smoker/drug user, enjoys outdoors/sports/travel, 'WELL Endowed', owns property, makes great money, successful

FA chairman Greg Dyke is proposing radical changes to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and change the definition of 'home-grown' to training in England for three years before age 18. He has the backing of five former England managers (Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren), who have signed a letter warning that blocking the proposals risks England falling further behind leading football nations. The Premier League opposes these changes. The motivation for the proposals is concern over the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the top level, noted by a low percentage of England-eligible Premier League starters (36.8%), and the need to provide opportunity for promising young players.

Based on the passage:

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby daughter in the show. This happens quickly in tomorrow night's episode. The passage highlights the rapid timeline of her pregnancy, noting she was barely showing last week and in tomorrow's episode goes from talking about being eight months pregnant to giving birth in minutes. Fans have noticed and commented on this fast timeline, comparing it to a previous pregnancy storyline (Elizabeth's). Ross Poldark is the father and is shown gazing lovingly at the baby. Ross's feelings for Demelza are mentioned (married out of

Based on the passage:

Leicester are bottom of the Barclays Premier League, three points from safety, despite back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 win at West Brom last week where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Manager Nigel Pearson urges his team to keep cool, ignore relegation rivals, and focus on their own games, stating their future is in their own hands. He warns against becoming overly optimistic after their mini-revival. Leicester hosts Swansea on Saturday.

Based on the passage:

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers). According to an Oregon State University study, she traveled from off Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous record of 10,190 miles by a humpback whale. The study's lead author, Bruce Mate, noted Varvara visited eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she might be from Mexico and potentially an eastern gray whale, despite being thought to be an endangered western gray whale. This suggests some western gray whales might be eastern grays, potentially lowering the estimated population of 150

On the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula, a stretch of seabed emerged overnight, rising as high as 50ft above sea level. This new land measures roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Geologists believe the emergence resulted from a nearby landslide caused by melting

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he is set to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating he is genuinely happy at the club and wants to sign a new contract. Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized and expensive in China (commanding prices up to Â£1.2 million), are now unpopular and being sent to slaughterhouses for meat (used in hotpots) and skin (used for leather belts). This dramatic decline is blamed partly on the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which stopped them being given as gifts to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. Urbanization also makes them less suited for city living, and poor breeding practices have resulted in a glut of low-quality dogs. Evidence includes rescued dogs found in cruel conditions being transported to slaughterhouses. Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to design prototype products addressing common "everyday emergencies." They asked people to identify their top emergencies, with not being able to sleep being the top issue in a survey of 2,000 people. Groups from design company Makerversity designed products, and three were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock silencing phone notifications for better sleep), Forget Me Lock (a device for a key showing if a door is locked or open), and Nipper (a small mobile phone charger using household batteries). The public can vote for their favorite prototype by retweeting tweets about them on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag. The prototype with the most retweets by April 40 will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other prototypes that did not make the shortlist included a parking pin, a relay app for messages when a phone dies, and a smart helmet with bone conduction headphones for directions.

Research indicates a decline in the frequency of sex among Britons since the internet emerged. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, revealed in his book "Sex by Numbers" that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990.

Possible reasons suggested for this decline include smartphone use, technology eroding boundaries between home and work, lives becoming busier due to connectivity, people checking emails frequently reducing quiet time, and sex falling down the list of priorities due to competing demands on time, making people too connected to focus on their partner at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized and expensive in China (commanding prices up to Â£1.2 million), are now unpopular and being sent to slaughterhouses for meat (used in hotpots) and skin (used for leather belts). This dramatic decline is blamed partly on the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which stopped them being given as gifts to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. Urbanization also makes them less suited for city living, and poor breeding practices have resulted in a glut of low-quality dogs. Evidence includes rescued dogs found in cruel conditions being transported to slaughterhouses. The dogs are large (up to 80 kg), traditionally used for herding, known for loyalty, and were previously seen as status symbols.

Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to design prototype products addressing common "everyday emergencies." They asked people to identify their top emergencies, with not being able to sleep being the top issue in a survey of 2,000 people. Groups from design company Makerversity designed products, and three were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock silencing phone notifications for better sleep), Forget Me Lock (a device for a key showing if a door is locked or open), and Nipper (a small mobile phone charger using household batteries). The public can vote for their favorite prototype by retweeting tweets about them on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag. The prototype with the most retweets by April 40 will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other prototypes that did not make the shortlist included a parking pin, a relay app for messages when a phone dies, and a smart helmet with bone conduction headphones for directions.
